newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: CURLING-CANADIAN RINK CLAIM RECORD THIRD TITLE.
newsitem.headline: CURLING-CANADIAN RINK CLAIM RECORD THIRD TITLE.

text.p: Sandra Schmirler led Canada to an 8-4 win over Norway in the final of the world curling championships on Saturday to become the first women's rink to claim three titles.
Schmirler's Regina foursome, winner of back-to-back crowns in 1993 and 1994, broke open a tight contest in the fifth end scoring five to jump ahead 6-1.

Norway's Dordi Nordby, the only other woman to win back-to-back titles, began to chip away at the lead taking one in the sixth then stealing singles in the seventh and eighth to narrow the deficit to 6-3.
But that would be as close as the Norwegian rink would come, as Canada scored two in the ninth to clinch their fourth title in five years.
With the win Canada become the early gold medal favourite in Nagano where curling will have full medal status for the first time.

"I've never been at an Olympics nobody has so I don't know what the pressure will be like," said Schmirler, who is five months pregnant and expecting her first child in August. "I think we are very lucky. Whichever team goes I think Canadians have to be realistic.
"Other countries know how to play this game and they're getting stronger and stronger."
In the bronze medal match Denmark beat Japan 7-6.
The men's final on Sunday will see Sweden take on Germany.
